Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: FRG: Understanding and Controlling Active Fluids through Modeling, Simulation, and Experiment
Award.AbstractNarration:
Soft active materials denote collections of particles, cells, or molecules that are capable to converting chemical energy from their environment into motion and mechanical stresses. Examples include swimming microorganisms, cellular extracts, biological polymers, and molecular motors, as well as a wealth of synthetic particles designed to mimic biological systems. These active systems, which have generated considerable excitement over the last decade in many disciplines from engineering to physics to applied mathematics, evince behaviors that are fundamentally different from traditional passive materials, and their understanding is just beginning to illuminate long-standing problems in biology and to suggest new engineering devices. This research project aims to use experiments, modeling, and simulations, to further enhance understanding of a variety of active materials. The project will also involve training through research involvement of postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduates.

The aim of this project is to use a combination of modeling, mathematical analysis, numerical simulations, and experiments to explore the dynamics of archetypal active fluids as their microstructural components interact with obstacles, walls, and each other. Computational and coarse-grained models will explore the interaction of microswimmers, individually and collectively, with boundaries and obstacles. Microfluidic environments will be fabricated to explore how active particle transport is affected and controlled by boundaries and obstacles, and tools of shape optimization will be used to guide the design. Specialized particles will be fabricated to elucidate different aspects of active matter. New types of active matter will be explored, both by considering modifications in particle-scale activity and system-scale confinement. These investigations will include detailed and coarse-grained computational models of recently synthesized active fluids in which immersed microtubules interact through motor-protein cross-linking and pulling, as well as a new active matter system in which particle activity couples to interfacial forces to drive large-scale flows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The emerging field of active matter describes the properties of materials whose microscopic constituents (cells, ATP-powered macromolecules, synthetic swimmers) are able to generate motion on small scales by relying on microscopic mechanical motors or chemical propulsion mechanisms. Examples include collections of swimming microorganisms such as bacteria, cell extracts where molecular motors act on structural filaments, as well as synthetic microscopic particles propelled by surface chemical reactions. Active particles and fluids evince behaviors that are fundamentally different from those of classical passive materials, including the emergence of self-regulating spontaneous motions, unusual transport properties and material responses. The major goal of this project was to further the basic understanding of these systems using a combination of modeling, analysis, computation, and comparisons with experimental data, with special focus on the interaction of active fluids with obstacles and boundaries and on the control of transport and dynamics by geometrical constraints.

Our models and simulations focused on explaining and predicting various aspects of the distributions and transport of swimming particles such as microorganisms in small spaces such as pipes, thin gaps between plates, or more complex porous materials. This problem, which is relevant to the transport of bacteria in soils, and the navigation of sperm and other swimming cells in the body as well as inside medical devices, is characterized by unusual transport properties where cells tend to accumulate near walls, swim upstream against fluid flows, and decrease the apparent viscosity of the fluid that carries them. In some cases, they are even able to self-organize into states where they collectively drive fluid motions on large length scales without any external actuation, thus behaving as self-pumping fluids. Our models and simulations provided mechanistic explanations for all of these various phenomena, which were shown to hinge on the coupling of particle orientations in the fluid flow they experience with their propulsion due to swimming in the presence of small-scale thermal fluctuations.

These research activities have served to enhance the fundamental understanding and modeling of a wide class of active materials in confined geometries. The theoretical and computational tools that were developed also serve as a basis for the predictive design of microscale devices aimed at guiding or controlling the dispersion of active swimmers. They should find applications in a wide range of problems in the fields of bioengineering, physics, and medicine, such as: biomedical devices, bioremediation and biodegradation processes, bacterial filtering among others.

This project also supported educational and outreach activities, notably through the participation of a postdoctoral fellow, a graduate research assistant, and several undergraduate researchers including three visiting summer interns from neighboring Tijuana, Mexico.
